I dunno.  I've been developing GUIs on a number of platforms for years, 
and I thought I was only doing very basic tool-oriented tasks, but I've 
never done a gui that reduces to a single component with a single 
message.  Maybe I just don't establish the proper concepts in the gui, 
but I invariably have several things interacting.

Yes, the right message gets sent to the Dialog, but the Dialog still 
doesn't show up.  Now what?  In my experience, the design space between 
two components is where I find the most bugs; it's rarely either one or 
the other but usually the interaction of the two that causes the problem 
or unexpected behavior.


On Tuesday, June 11, 2002, at 09:36 AM, Bob Koss wrote:

> On 6/11/02 7:28 AM, "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@...>
> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> Bob Koss [mailto:koss@...] wrote:
>>> But if we use Mediator to decouple the gui controls, we may as
>>> well delegate
>>> everything to the Mediator and leave the gui stupid. The Mediator can 
>>> be
>>> unit tested just like any other class, and doesn't need the gui since 
>>> all
>>> communication is done through interfaces.
>>
>> That notwithstanding, you still need to test the connection between the
>> mediator and your GUI. There's still plenty of room for error there.
>
>
> I'm trying to understand your concern. I can test that the Mediator 
> send the
> right message with the right parameters at the right time. The code in 
> the
> gui (let's say a Dialog box just to be concrete) that responds to this
> message is one or two lines of code which IMO, can't break.
>
> Can you show me in a few lines of code where there is room for error 
> between
> the Mediator and the gui/dialog/whatever?
